[h1]It's not a hardcore game, Survival activity? Nah, Let the monkey do it![/h1]
　Before Palworld gained mainstream popularity for enslaving Pokémon-like monsters, we had The survivalists who enslaved monkeys.

[H3]Review :[/h3]

        [th]　　About[/th]

    [tr]
        [td]Gᴀᴍᴇᴘʟᴀʏ[/td]
        [td]　
　Ah, I thought this game would be another Don't Starve-like experience, but I was wrong. It's an interesting survival game involving crafting, gathering, and sailing to other islands. Of course, you can have a monkey do all the tasks by either saving them from a cage or giving them some food. They don't seem to have perfect AI. for example, a monkey delivering loot to a crafting station might be intercepted by another monkey returning it back to crate. But, it is what it is.

　To make it clear, this game has the worst buttons I've ever played with. It doesn't follow the usual button mapping you would expect, though luckily, it has binding support, which helped a lot. The basics of the game rely on trial and error, leading me to regenerate my island three times to understand the game. Fortunately, you can bring your character to a regenerated island and join someone else's room, which I think is a plus. However, the menu for managing characters isn't as simple as in Terraria, which is a bummer because Terraria offers a better UI experience and menu. Overall, the gameplay was great, though I don't mind the combat in this game, it could become chaotic when a raid happens, and you may need to gather as many monkeys as possible to help you.
　[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gʀᴀᴘʜɪᴄ[/td]
        [td]　
　Well, I like the simple graphics. it's similar to those free Unity assets you might discover online when learning Unity. However, the only complaint I have is that this game is essentially locked to the specified requirements. It lacks advanced graphic settings like the ability to turn off shadows or bloom. I know it's not a big issue for many people, but I lean more towards helping low-spec users than the spoiled playstation generation ones. That's all. it's more beautiful than Don't Starve, but on the downside, the gameplay isn't as deep as Don't Starve.
　[/td]

Of course, it's not a problem since public rooms usually have issues. For instance, in Don't Starve, you might join a US dedicated server and encounter a trolling player party who kick you with his Steam name 'blank' Unfortunately, the developers of that game don't seem to do anything about those trolls. That's one of the reasons why I jumped into other survival games, like this one.

157664145.review:
A worthy game if you got it during 90% discount, but can't say so for the full price.

It is simply a great survival-craft genre to play alone or with friends during your short window of holidays.
The overall game is fun with a unique literal "monkey see monkey do" mechanic.
Keep in mind that the game (by the time I wrote this) only has 30-40 hours of content and almost no replayability value.

For me, the only issue is that during multiplayer session, most item are locked only for the host. So, if you want to unlock those stuff, you need to progress your own world (especially if you are aiming for the achievements). Not a biggie, but it's not that fun to replay this game due to it's linear progression.

Nonetheless, it's still a fun "one-shot change of pace" game for those who likes survival-craft genre.

158290611.review:
I really REALLY want to like this game! As kid's we'd use pencil and paper to play the "island game" of living on a deserted island and building huts, growing trees, etc. The Survivalists has charming graphics and good game design that gets overshadowed by the tedium of it. 

Unless I'm missing a mechanic unlocked later in the game, you need to craft basic items, like vines, individually and then combine them into other crafting before using that item at a specialist building to get upgrades to tools that will break unless you repair them. This is just tedious and worsened by the fact that you need to strip mine / deforest locations to get enough resources for one upgraded tool.

This game works well as a skinner box drip feeding progression. With quality of life improvements like instant crafting of basic items (looking at you large rocks and vines), the ability to auto-craft basic items in advanced item crafting menus, and the addition of better automation (not a per monkey affair), I'd be willing to keep going. Maybe it gets better once you're a few hours in, but I'd have more fun in minecraft or don't starve by then.

In short, this isn't a bad game at all. It's charming. I'm just not ready to spend multiple hours before it becomes fun.

157725627.review: If you like survival games to also play with friends, this is a good game I would mainly recommend due to its creativity and survival techniques. You can build and research so many things to help you survive e.g. a forge that also allows you to build many crafting recipes. Things in this game like raids from other goblins, animals to kill for loot to craft and eat, upgrades in weaponry and tools, huge map and mysteries, monkeys to help you with things like crafting, fighting, gathering, mining materials like wood or stone and much more is what makes this game amazing. A recommendation I would give for this game currently is to have the ability to rotate blueprints before placing them for a better experience (at least that i don't know of).

158881525.review: this is a great game for those who enjoy sandbox-fighting adventure games (like stardew). there's lots to do in this game like quests, crafting items, achieving recipes, rescuing monkey, fighting bosses, and unlocking new maps. it's also fun how much you can play around with the monkeys: delegating tasks, fighting, and watching them level up. the maps also frequently regenerate, mobs and loot (ores, plants, trees, etc) so you never really have to wait around to collect things. though you have to grind quite a bit to achieve a certain stat, it's very manageable with so many monkeys helping you as you go. highly recommend this game!

77294091.review:
The gameplay loop is fine and typical of a survival game but the crafting progression and the game as a whole feels very limited. The survival consists only of hunger (and thirst in some biomes apparently) which is satiated pretty easily and suits the casual atmosphere of the game. The Monkey system is a pretty creative solution to grinding out resources and building/crafting. 

However, after about 2 hours I had unlocked nearly every crafting blueprint and never had to leave the first island until I needed metal. With everything unlocked and no real need to set up a major main base (nor are there really any buildings that need a ton of resources which would necessitate a main base) I found the repetitive nature pretty underwhelming.

Considering how little content there is and how essentially non-existent the "story" is, I feel no need to dive back in despite a pretty satisfying gameplay loop. It seems over priced - more like an Early Access release in terms of content. Maybe the updates they promise will flesh out more of what the game could be.
77294091.developer_response:
Hey there,

Sorry to hear you dropped off after the second hour.

We're listening and taking action on a lot of the amazing community feedback right now. We've already began to make quality of life tweaks to the difficulty and overall game flow/progression to make the pace much more even. Plus lowering the power of monkeys in combat, making enemies more numerous and tougher among many crafting tweaks. 

We'll also be adding more content in the future and will be supporting the game and listening to feedback a long the way.

You can try this patch on the experimental branch: https://steamcommunity.com/games/897450/announcements/detail/4691021366605126614

Though it will be coming very soon to live!

We hope you'll give the game another go.

77401310.review:
Edit: Strokethrough a few lines to reflect the current patch. Recommendation remains the same.

The game starts nice and simple... and stays just nice and simple throughout, just with more monkeys. I'd say it is correctly described by the "casual" tag, just... too casual for the asking price. I've tried to find its charm, but its flaws and deficiencies far outweigh its nice things.

The premise of the game is promising, but the execution is poor. Other than aesthetics, your character is exactly the same from the beginning to the end; no skills, experience, stats improvements, etc. The survival aspect is absolutely minimal, with only a very limited stamina pool, some mostly negligible hunger meter, health and the ever present you-must-consume-potion-to-survive-biome gimmick. There are tiered weapons and tools, but these are mostly wasted on you, as your monkeys can use them more efficiently, both due to their increasing skill stat and from sheer number of them... and then there is little incentive to use anything beyond the basic stuff.

[strike]Speaking of monkeys, the novelty of the game is quickly brought down by poor execution, and terrible controls/interaction. If you have two or three monkeys, it is mostly fine, but 5+ become incredibly annoying to manage. From terrible interactions with other parts of the game, to a faulty user interface, managing the army you will accrue becomes not a chore, but an annoyance.[/strike]

I truly don't know what exactly this game is about. It's not survival, as the "survival" elements can be mostly ignored or have a trivial solution. Not base building, as your options as fairly limited [strike]and you have no incentive to defend or improve,[/strike] and everything is almost literally dirt-cheap. Not combat, as it is solved with low-tier weapons handled to enough monkeys. Not AI-based automation, since there is no real depth to the crafting system, the AI is quite lacking and you can't do anything to compensate for it.

I cannot recommend this game at the time.

If you want details...

- Crafting and "survival": The game has a "one button for all" contextual scheme, [strike]which combined with the inescapable need to manually pick up, one by one, the pignata-level loot from mostly everything, makes it so that you will very frequently end up giving your pickaxe to your bow monkey, who promptly runs away with it and blends with your army before you can recover it, when you wanted to pick up the couple rubies you needed among the ton of overabundant crap on the floor[/strike]. This, combined with the [strike]ludicrously[/strike] limited inventory (which cannot be actually upgraded, mind you) [strike], the ever so infuriating chest-carrying monkeys that run away from you when you want to access your "extended" inventory[/strike], the frustrating crafting tree, and so many obnoxious little big things, make the "survival" part of the game quite the annoyance after the first hour of gameplay. Numerous "survival" mechanics are just shallow, with barely any impact on your game experience. Health is pretty standard. Stamina is treated like a souls-like thing, with a pool that would allow just a couple rolls, or swings from your weapon/axe/pick, before you are "too tired"... but recover completely a few seconds later with no real penalty (seriously, if you overexert, the stamina will recover FASTER than if you had managed your resource). Also, there are biomes in the game, that will require you to progress in your tech/crafting-tree or buy from the in-game merchant to get immunity from the barely annoying life-draining gimmick they induce... fairly standard I guess, but lacks any kind of sense of progression nor carry a narrative punch.

- Combat: It exists, but your undying monkeys are more than enough to handle everything in the game. You don't need the sky-rendering, earth-sundering, eleventh-hour sword, just give three monkeys a couple bone and steel clubs and you are done. There are periodic "raids" to your base, which mostly consists of a couple baddies clumsily clubbing at your stuff and house-keeping monkeys. All the structures you build are mostly made out of overabundant materials, like pebbles, sticks and leaves, so all true incentive to defend comes from the mild inconvenience of resetting the blueprints, while your monkeys do all the work... or maybe why bother at all! Just set another camp on another island, why not.

- Interface, user experience and AI: Awful, terrible, abysmal. From the [strike]"everything is solid, you cannot walk here because there is some bush/rock/tree/unidentified piece of rubble obscured by foliage/mountain", the[/strike] "you want to craft the frequently used D? Well, you better start manually crafting several Cs, a ton of Bs and innumerable As, all made from pebbles and grass... and progressively just adding more grass and pebbles to each product", [strike]to the "which one of you monkeys has my axe?!", "I just wanted to train ONE monkey!",  "What do you mean you forgot you were following me when I reloaded the save?!",[/strike] "Billy the miner has once again walked all the way to Mordor and his pick is busted... I guess the only reasonable thing for him to do is to jump in place there and wait, while his siblings decide to use the handful of pebbles all the way to Mordor to make an axe for him, ignoring the practically infinite stacks already sitting in a chest right by the crafting table", the game is plagued with little frustrating things, that cannot pass by anything other than a blatant flaw in design.
77401310.developer_response:
Hey Ebdo,

Sorry you didn't have an epic time!

We have released a Quality of Life and Fix patch (1.1) that followed several experimental patches based on community feedback. 

There have been big changes on overall game progression, how strong monkeys are and many changes aimed at ironing out player frustrations. Things like lost monkeys have been fixed. Monkeys in combat are now much weaker, but can also default to combat without needing to be trained every time. Structures now need slightly more resources and monkeys overall are harder to tame, requiring more resources and advanced things. 

We've also added several more key bindings.

You can read the big list of changes here: https://steamcommunity.com/games/897450/announcements/detail/2957136048936781984

We wanted to show everyone we're commited to making the game the best it can be and this has been the first step.

We hope you will give the game another chance! :)

77452618.review:
I highly do not recommend this game, if you expected a game with a decent amount of content and replayability, this isn't the game for you. There is little to no content and you experience most of the content in less then 3hours, its not worth the asking price and If I could I would refund this game.

The Tech tree is tiny and what exists is mainly useless.
Building in this game is pretty much pointless, you don't need a permanent base as everything is so easily built and there is no indepth tech requirements.
Majority of Cooking is next to pointless, since it really only gives you hp and potentially useless buffs. The reason why hp is useless is cause the enemies don't really scale at all, there are very few enemy types and once you get any metal weapon it becomes a walk in the park.
The whole monkey system is pretty cool, but its also pretty pointless - the only time I used the monkeys was to help build all the materials to end the game - aside from that there was little use to them, since they get stuck in the labyrinths if you meet a spike pit.

There just isn't enough content, its basically a cheap mobile app game that you play for acouple of days then finish and put down. Its not worth 1/3rd of a AAA game.

78319737.review:
This is a super cute, should-be-fun take on a game like Stardew Valley, Terraria, etc.  I love the concept so much. But the execution is horrible. NOTHING is intuitive (why do I have to equip my multi-tool every time I want to craft? If it's in my bag, it should craft).  Why are there 2987592387434 buttons to do one task? Why do the monkeys constantly forget the tasks they were assigned?  Why can't my co-op teammate use the mystery chest if I allow chest sharing?

The tutorial is not very informative or helpful and there aren't many guides available for this game yet.  It definitely feels like an early access game, so $25 for what feels like an unfinished game that lacks content feels like robbery.

Really needs to work on quality of life updates (maybe upgrading inventory space at the mysterious stranger, sharing mystery chests, better tutorial) to be good at this price point.

156289722.review:
The Survivalists is a beautiful survival game set in a Robinson Crusoe atmosphere.

You start as a castaway and have to collect resources to make various things. Either other players in Multiplayer, or a group of trainable monkeys in Singleplayer help you crafting and building. The aim is to escape the archipelago, various islands can be explored by raft.

Overall, I really like the game and recommend it.

77364531.review:
Think this game looks great? play the demo. You have now played 80% of the game, so don't bother buying it.
Pros:
-Demo has multiplayer
-Multiplayer with friends is fun for a couple of hours
Cons:
-Repetitive gameplay loop
-Monkeys break the balance of the game
-Very limited options in all aspects of the game
-Combat is boring, and using monkeys makes it super easy to steamroll through it
-it is possible to streamroll through the whole content without too much effort
-Once you have gone through one vault, you've basically gone through all of them

Overall, the game has potential, but the lack of actual gameplay makes it feel like an early access game, rather than the finished version. This game is in no way worth 25$,; its worth no more than 10$.

109149983.review:
Monkey see… monkey do. I’m sure this is not the first review that started with those words, but it sums up much of the game. I’ve put in just over 70 hours on the game and feel I have a pretty good handle on it.


The Basics

You start the game ship wrecked, alone on an island. You little guy can gather resources of various types (wood, rock, etc) and build basic tools (flimsy axe, flimsy pickaxe, etc). Eventually you build a workstation, which allows you to build more things. Eventually you’ll build walls and floors and make a base. You can also farm and tame wild life to more efficiently acquire resources. Also you’ll make a raft and explore new islands with unique biomes with specific resources and enemies.

Of course the highlight and unique quality of the game is the monkeys. As you explore the world, you’ll find monkeys in cages or monkeys just hanging around an area asking for a specific item. Once you free them or give them the item, they become one of your monkey minions. Any monkey minion can be trained to do a specific task by putting the monkey minion into “learn” mode, and have them watch you do a task (like chopping down a tree). You can also have them follow you, and if you give them a weapon, they will protect you (or at least try). I found this feature similar to the robots in Autonauts, but simplified considerably.

The research tree is very simple. When you build an item in the tree, the next items become available. This is true for the initial construction, and the more advanced construction (using workstation, forge, etc). Further in the game you buy technologies from various sellers or gain them by beating bosses.

There are NPCs throughout the world who will buy and sell things with you. There are bosses to beat.  There are different biomes. 

The ultimate goal is to find and fix a ship so that you can escape the islands.


Things to Consider Before Buying

The game is simple and easy to pick up and play. I also found I could advance pretty quickly which was fun. But I also found the fun ran out quickly. Although I put in 70 hours, I had completely all the “real” research, built all the “real” weapons and tools, beaten some bosses and was pretty much done with the game around the 20 hour mark. I felt bad about writing a review with so few hours though, so I pushed through looking for more depth, but I found the game lacking in depth. 

The game has advanced research and weapons. But they are missing two key components. First, I couldn’t find any part of the game where the advanced research and weapons were needed. I could do everything with the basic stuff. Second, after an additional 50 hours, I had only acquired a couple of the advanced research and/or item, due to the need to gather tons of resources over and over just to hit the goals to get the research and/or item. The monkeys minions are great assistants, but a lot of it has to be done manually, like moving to a new area and telling the monkeys to cut down every tree in sight, then gather the wood, move to the next area, etc. I like grinding games and usually find the grinding component of a game quite rewarding, but I found this went beyond grinding and was actually tedious and not fun.

Due to the grinding to get to the advanced part of the game, I found there was a serious gap between the basic and the advanced parts of the game so I searched for anything that might be considered mid-game filler. About the only thing I found was NPC “quests”. But the “quests” made no real sense. For example, one NPC was in an area with enemies that can’t be conquered at the beginning of the game, yet the NPC’s quests were tutorial in nature, like build 8 straw walls and a door. Then build 8 wooden walls and a door. Then build 8 wooden floors. But by that time in the game, my base was well established and I was well beyond any need for tutorials. There was a real feeling that the NPC quests were an afterthought, were unbalanced, and really didn’t fit in with the game.

Resource storing in grinding games is essential and expected. In this game resources are stored in chests. But the game is missing basic things, like being able to sort resources in a chest. Or use a button to transfer everything from your inventory into a chest. Or like in terraria where you can stand near a bunch of chests, press a button, and the items are instantly transferred to the chests that already contain those item (one of the best features I’ve seen in any resource grinding game). The game does try to address this issue. When a monkey minion is ordered to pick up items and place them in chests, the monkey minion will try to find a chest that already contains that item before randomly placing the item in another chest. But this behaviour fails very quickly if the chest becomes full, or if the chest is outside of the monkey minion’s work zone. 

The area the monkey minions will work in is finite, and you’ll often find your monkey minions standing beside a tree, complaining they can’t find a tree to chop down because they have hit the edge of their work zone. Unfortunately this zone is invisible and although appeared consistent, after 70 hours I still could not accurately place my monkey minions so they covered the area I wanted. Although this may not seem important, it is compounded with the issues below.

Farming becomes necessary to gather resources more quickly in the later parts of the game. Using 4 monkey minions, they can be trained to plant the seed (one), water the crop (two), harvest the crop (three), and place the harvest in a chest (four). This also applies to farming trees. But you can’t tell the monkey which seed to use. So while you may have initially planted grass in your farm, you may come back to your base and find the farm is completely growing berries instead. I could not find a simple solution to fix this. I tried placing a chest will only the seeds I wanted used. I tried moving all other seeds further away, hoping they were outside the monkey minion’s work zone. The only solution I could see working (which I did not try) is to have each farm built a good distance away from each other. But then gathering the resources together to build something would become tedious instead.

The last thing to consider is the training of the monkey minions. As I mentioned above, the monkeys are fun, but only for a time. As I past the 20 hour mark and needed the monkey minions to perform accurately and efficiently, I found them quite annoying. First, each monkey minion can only be trained to do one basic action, like planting a seed or watering the seed. It can’t do both. Second, there are no logic mechanisms in the game, such as checking to see if a chest is full, or how many of an item are available. This becomes very problematic, and prevents full automation. For example, there is no way to have a monkey minion continuously make a tool to ensure there are always exactly 20 available. You either have the monkey continuously make the tool, using up all of the resources required to make the tool. Or you can specify how many of an item to make. When those are used up though, you have to manually initiate another build. If you forget, or are away from the base for a while, your monkey minions will stop working, allowing items to run out. The lack of logic mechanisms makes it impossible to completely automate the building process.

So the bottom line – would I recommend the game? As long as none of the issues above will bother you, then I would. For me, I very much enjoyed the first 20 hours, but found I was more frustrated than having fun for the additional 50 hours.

77590067.review:
This game was released as a 1.0 version product. This means that it's feature complete (NOT an Alpha) and it's tested (NOT a Beta). As such, as a reviewer, I can only in good faith review it as such. I am aware of future announcements for the game and the promise of more content, but if the developers wanted it reviewed that way, they should have released it as an Alpha (feature incomplete) in Early access. This game DOES have some potential, but I won't review a title based off promises. As it stands, this title feels like a product, not a game. It seems like an idea that was cobbled together to make 30 minutes of playable game so that youtubers and advertisers can exploit children. I'll be happy to be mistaken, but that's the impression I get.

As an additional preword, I didn't like The Escapists and think they wouldn't have looked out of place on Kongregate or some other free flash game website.

While The Escapists I would describe as ankle deep, this title I would describe as knee deep. What you're doing at one point in the game won't change much to what you're doing 5 hours later. While in other survival titles might see you advance through a dynamic tech tree, figuring things out as you go and gatherering materials, this title sees you follow a linear and static tech tree as you sit around watching monkeys auto gather and your numbers get higher like a mobile game. There is absolutely no "Survival" to speak of. Food is immediately abundant, you don't drink, you don't get cold or hot, sick, poisoned, diseased or anything that might be considered "survival". Survival itself doesn't even seem to be a consideration in this survival game. As a title in the genre, it feels like it was made by lizards who saw the fundamental elements of every successful game, then they proceeded to remove all of the fun and replace it with a sterile version of what a survival title is when written on a piece of paper and read by an executive that's never played a videogame.

The monkeys themselves are a core component of the gameplay. Your human character with a fully developed brain can't learn anything, in fact getting WORSE at most tasks as they continue to do it, complaining about how "Bored" they are by having to literally stay alive. Conversely, the monkeys level up and get better at tasks, get more efficient at using tools and are generally just better at everything, tool usage included. Then the monkey training happens and it's counter intuitive. You want to train a monkey to haul things to a workstation. You enter training mode and show him how to do it. But because you didn't access a chest and take an item out during the training, the monkey will only deliver items that are left on the ground. Now okay. This makes sense. "Realism" or whatever. So why can monkeys learn better than a human? The game flip-flops over itself trying to balance "reality" with "fun" and fails at every conceivable junction. Like every single opportunity where the developers thought; "Do we make this realistic or make it enjoyable for the player?", they never chose to make it enjoyable to the player. You're left with an experience that feels like a chore. In many other survival titles, you're doing chores but it's fun. In this title, you're playing a game and it feels like doing chores and I can't descibe why, which is why I'm convinced it was designed by lizards who just don't understand the human brain. All the parts are there and it should be fun, but it isn't.

This title is nearly half the price of Cyberpunk 2077. Just let that sink in for a moment before you purchase it and then maybe wait for a sale. Support the developers if you actually believe they're going to improve, but for a general audience, there's absolutely no way that I would suggest someone buy this title. Go play Green Hell or Minecraft or something. At least you'll get a feeling at some point during the game that you need to survive.

120736347.review:
A decent game up until I got completely softlocked right before the finale.
It's your typical Survival Craft fare, but you have monkeys that help automate tasks.
I disagree with some of the reviews that it is grindy. It's only grindy if you don't use the monkeys, as they can do everything you can up to 5 times faster. The long build times are to incentivize you into using them instead of doing it yourself.
I feel like content-wise it's a bit shallow, but for what it is it's enjoyable. 

The only reason I'm not recommending it is because of the horrible save-system that made it impossible to get out of the aforementioned softlock (Yes i'm a bit salty).  You can only save while in a bed, the game does have an autosave but since the game only keeps 1 save file per game it writes over the bed save. So I got stuck in the sea, quit to look for a solution, and then came back to find that since there's only 1 save file I could not rollback to a previous save and was stuck. You'd think in CURRENT YEAR there wouldn't still be such archaic save systems being implemented.

81758410.review:
Farming update first impressions edit.
-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-
TLDR;
The last update just gone and put kerosene in the now dumpster fire, the whole "Nerf" to the wooden club just destroyed early game in a way i wasn't sure was possible, i'm now just staring at the state of early game, the wooden club was used as an early game collecting tool and now it is actually useless, it would not be so bad if again we hadat least a crude axe but no, this is bad, am i overreacting, maybe, do i care, no.

It's an incomplete game, even in it's current state it's not; The game systems feel a couple of iteration cycles away from optimal, my main concern is that the game will stay in this state, feeling clunky and full of sub-optimal systems and sub-systems.

When i frist saw this game it reminded me of Don't Starve, that game is my favorite PC game of all time, it has a very similar "challenge structure" with the Raids every so often, "caves" are there to give more loot, but, it lacks a lot of things that i will detail in this post:

-The 1.0 version feels unfinished; it needs more polish in systems and varaiety in Loot, i just don't have space for all the shovels and multitools, chests would be better filled with wood and that is sad.

-The "Programable AI" (Monkeys) are useless in small numbers; simple, the AI can't do more than one thing, balanced, but tedious.

-The monkey "Job System" is cumbersome,  i don't think it is implemented to it's fullest potential; also simple, you have to "teach" the monkey the job if you want it to do, if you want it to do more than one thing you have to re-teach a previous "job", balanced but tedius and lefts monkeys idle 90% of the time a simple menu to re-do jobs it has done in the past would help a lot.

-The crafting system, the core of the game, is boring and tedious, like in Don't Starve you have a begining set of recipes, however unlike DS this set of recipes does not include basic level tools, you require the work station that is a building that takes sone hand-precessed resources and an aditional time cuota to craft this station, and the tools are not there-after available as a hand craftable, they are still work station dependant, this in so annoying, not only because you managed to make early game horribly time consuming and luck dependant but you also made mid and late game resource gathering an exercise in more planning that it should, just because if you not have the tool you need in your monkey chest you have to go all the way back to base to pick up a new axe or invest the time to put the crafting station, if you either make the crafting station portable or the recipe unlocked after the fact this would fix a lot of problems i have with the game itself, this is now a worse point there is no longer a viable early game collecting tool this may destroy the whole game...

-The recipes are very grindy; the ones you feel you need require a lot of materials and are behind other recipes that sometimes require the sema materials, sometimes doubling the grind.

-The combat is an aweful mix of systems; a dodge-counter combat in wich more likely than not you are facing more than a couple of enemies, its doable but for each extra enemy the guaranted damage you'll take go up and the likelihood of succes go down in an equal manner, you could give a monkey a club, but the contribution of a monkey is barely worth not having the monkey carry a chest or pick up loot or crating, only becuase the game developers made those actions extremly tedious, this was made somewhat more awefull in the Farming Update, weapons feel more unresponsive and tend to miss alot more, the new timing was not well recived by me.

-The whole Raid incursion thing i didn't seem to have any warning, that was annoying. (Fixed.)

-Spears are useless, the enemy moves too much and the attack angles are very restrictive, a woden club works better 60% of the time for close encounters and the Bow outclasses it always as a ranged weapon. (Bows can't damage trees nor rocks, this balances them somewhat, spearst are still not very usefull.)

-The whole crafting system feels incomplete; even after you grind all the materials there is no significant upgrade, no armor, no unique weapon, all feels the same.
-Currently there is an "END" to the game, not an advanced stege in the final expansion of the tech tree or a truly Difficult Last Boss, the game just ends with a Gag and you are back to square one; this confuses me, it feels like the developerss rushed to have a definitive END to the game and forgot to put content in the middle part of it. (Somewhat fixed, still no real objective for all the systems tho, Fixed???)

EDIT.

The developers are not helping its own game, with every update it gets more bloated and important things appear not to be in the radar for near updates armor and early game collecting, so yeah, not fun for the moment.

98071275.review:
Well I was really hoping this game was going to be as fun as the trailers made it look. I even played the demo before it released and was pretty pumped for what was to come. However, what was released is most certainly lacking. This game feels half finished. It feels like they meant to add a lot more into it but then couldn't fit it in. A lot of the mechanics are broken or just shouldn't work the way they do. A prime example of this is, if you play with someone else online, only the host unlocks the recipes that aren't connected to the recipe unlock tree. Your teammates will not be able to unlock the bomb recipe so you will have to craft those for them. Backpacks? They can buy it but won't receive the recipe. It's very frustrating and almost made us quit the game. But we decided to just finish it. Also, I think there needs to be better markers on how to make progress because honestly in the beginning we were just like uhh what now a lot of the time. 

One of the most frustrating parts of this game was hands down the tools. They break so fast. Like it's actually stupid. You are constantly repairing your tools just for you to maybe get through half a labyrinth and they are already worn down again. And it doesn't get better with the better tools you craft, especially when it comes to your sword. I don't know who thought it was a good idea to barely get any use out of the tools. 

The raids are pointless, if I'm being perfectly honest. You don't get anything special from them. They are the same enemies that you fought on that island before. They are more an annoyance than anything. Not really any point. Same goes for the treasure, the rewards for tracking it down just aren't worth it unless you're dead set on doing them. 

We did finish the game and honestly it was just lacking. Like there wasn't any reason to stay and there wasn't any reason to finish. They definitely wanted this game to have replay value but it frankly just doesn't. Just doesn't feel like a complete game. Maybe this will change in the future but we will not be coming back to this game unless major updates are had.

Its frustrating when I can't open a chest if there's an item sitting on the ground in front of it because the [space] key operates both picking up the item and opening up the chest. 139161914.review:
Interesting concept and nice graphics but not worth it. Janky across the board from placing things in the world to the crafting system and menu navigation (renaming, selecting items, etc.) Co-op has significant restrictions on non-host players limiting their freedom to play (limited monkeys they control, non-hosts cannot destroy objects). Saving works inconsistently - sometimes the game will not save for whatever reason (my friend and I lost 4 hours of progress despite saving multiple times at the bed in that time frame).

Ultimately, the game is interesting and has potential, but with the short length combined with the jankiness and bugs I would not recommend this game at full price. Get it on sale and go in prepared to deal with unrefined systems and hope your game actually saves. I would also recommend playing single player as it seems that was what the game was intended for.

99971020.review:
On one hand it's a really fun style of game, and having monkeys to do your tasks is a great way of having the game get easier as you progress. I easily put in a little over 20 hrs just eager to get the next crafting material, get to the next island, find another monkey, upgrade my items, and so on. And to be clear, I had a lot of fun doing so. However, right around when I had nine monkeys, I realized that I'd go on these huge trips with my monkeys so I could gather materials, (maybe 30-45min trips) just to get back and blow through the important materials instantly. It was like every trip to an island was just to gather materials for the immediate next trip for the next island. I realized I was just wasting my time going around in circles.

Let's break it down:

-Monkey management is a pain in the ass. I wish there were two modes I could have saved so I didn't have to manually reset them every time I went to an island, and then every time I got back to base.
-They do no put items in a single chest, the randomly scatter everything (why is there no whitelist/blacklist on chests??)
-You need one monkey to supply items, one to craft the item, and one to put it away. But the monkeys do not communicate with each other at all. So if I'm crafting an item that needs to go into another item and both are queued, when the first item gets made, the storage monkey will pick it up and put it in a random chest only to have the supplier monkey immediately have to go and get it. I would think the storage monkey would check with the other AI to see if the item is needed. Supplying/Storage should be one job.
-Monkeys will plant whatever damn seeds they want, so you have to literally store all your other seeds outside of their control
-Monkeys glitch frequently enough. It's not game breaking but more than I would expect
-When having your monkeys preform a task, they will complete that task in what I assume is  certain sized area before stopping (so that they don't just go across the whole island), but then you have to re-educate them. It would be so much easier if they retained their teaching and you could just hit a button to reset the order in the next area
-It's a pain to remember what monkeys do what. Color code them if you want to keep your sanity
-Monkeys will deal more damage than you, and will cause less wear on weapons when using them. You're essentially meant to do nothing but stand around your monkeys
-Certain materials are way to scarce and the crafting ratio of them is totally out of balance. I'm looking at you hardwood. You can suck it. A whole trip to an island and I get 45 hardwood stumps, which for whatever dumb reason requires 3 stumps to make 1 plank? And then you want me to use 10 planks to build a ladder?? Are you serious?

I'm so torn with this game. If they just made some quality of life improvements and change the crafting ratios on some things, this would be an amazing game. As is, it's worth the $8.50 I paid, and the week worth of fun I had, but there are a thousand games on steam like that. Guess I'm just disappointed that it so narrowly misses the mark.

84122778.review:
I normally don't leave reviews because I just cant be bothered sometimes, even for games that aren't great. But this one made me upset.

This game is absolutely, 100%, without a doubt, NOT worth the price. I have played games that have cost less and have significantly more content. You could literally play the demo and experience the majority of the game. 

I see reviews on here about how thats simply not true. That theres more content in the full game than there is in the demo. Yes, that's true. But not that much more. When you play the demo, you can actually see the crafting tree, most of which is locked. That is exactly what is available in the full game. There is no hidden crafts, there is no unlockable crafts. All of those little squares you see in the demo is what you get. Thats it. 

The monkeys. They're cute and I love them, but they are absolutely useless. They are annoyingly to train and can literally only do one thing at a time. Each time you want it to do something else, you have to retrain it. Even if its learned it before. Combat wise, its fine to have the monkeys around, but you really, really, really don't need them. In fact, my friends and I did a dungeon or whatever and the monkeys got stuck somewhere. We literally just abandoned them there because there was no need for them to help us with combat and it was too annoying to go and find ALL of the monkeys in our monkey hoard before we moved on. 

There are multiple islands, which you'd think would be great, right? Nope. The islands were very meh. Each new island has one or two new things on it - new ore, new terrain or new beasts. We completed the game without ever going into the swamp (I don't even know what the point of it was). 

When we finished the game, we realized that you could literally play this game and finish it in a few hours. It only took my group 8 hours because we took forever figuring out what was going on on the starter island. We got to the second island, set up camp then realized there was literally no point to set up camp. We blew through the rest of the islands by just going to them, running to the dungeon thing and then leaving. 

I will not be buying any more of their games in the future, especially not on release. 

TL;DR I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone. Everyone one of my friends who played this game ended up disappointed at having spent so much money on a game that wasn't worth it. If you are typically a casual gamer or like games that are simple and cute, maybe get this game on sale.

95854613.review:
This is a very good title for anyone looking to start or get someone started on survival games! It is also a great game for anyone looking for a low-stress survival/building game. I got my 70 year old Dad playing this and he loves it with over 187 hours logged so far and still counting (he took over the entire home island as his base).

So here are the good, the bad and the ugly of it 

The Good:   The monkey automation is fantastic at this stage though it does need some tweaking to perhaps assign single monkeys to a specific workstation IE: this monkey only crafts things at the Forge and ignores other work stations.  

The Islands are fairly large and robust with resources and threats. The larger labyrinths while being big are not so large that they are tedious to walk around in special thanks for the teleporter to the exit in the boss rooms. Crafting trees unlock automatically after making the recipe that precedes them. The hunger meter does not deplete so rapidly that you have to eat every 5 seconds.

The monkey controls while complex seeming are easily learned even by a 70 year old with bad eye sight (Dad if you're reading this I love you XD ). Defenses are easy to build and easy to maintain if you assign a monkey to be on repair duty. The monkeys are best suited for crafting and base maintenance.  I generally take 6 monkeys with me 5 fighters and 1 to carry a chest.

The Bad: The monkeys have hard limits that are either not defined not addressed or not shown. For example monkeys that water your crops will only water so many (no matter how close or far apart the crop plots are to one another) before it will water no more.  

Monkeys that are assigned to craft things will leave the bench they are working at to go to another bench. This may not seem like a problem but when you have 2 or more crafting stations and already have a craft monkey and want to assign an extra monkey to help craft you have to be quick or you have to stop the first monkey to add the extra one. The reason for this is that the original craft monkey will run up to the craft station you are assigning the new monkey to and start crafting the item you are trying to get the new monkey to craft effectively blocking your mimic command on that monkey.

Sometimes monkeys get blocked behind structures they have built IE: base walls. Monkeys can get "stuck" at sea. When you die the monkeys try to get back to you but end up spread all over the island you died on forcing you to run around and call them back. Cant breakdown rafts.

The Ugly: You can't place any decorations or lights on side walls. Base walls even metal ones are easily destroyed by creatures such as orclings, boars, and deer (really deer and boar destroying a metal wall come on Team 17 that makes no sense). 

Some items after Expeditions update have no purpose (i'm looking at you dried seed pod husk) due to changed recipes, but were still left in the game. The sturdy bow is the only bow worth making the others are so weak it takes half their "arrows" to kill even a small animal.  Giving high tier weapons to monkeys seems to make the weapon weaker IE: monkeys do less damage then the player even with end game weapons. 
 
The game does not give you enough quest tokens to buy all the trinkets but will offer you multiple copies of a trinket to buy from the hot air balloon guy. I found that out the hard way buy buying a trinket that was later given to me as a blueprint. Now there is a trinket blueprint I have to buy from said hot air balloon guy that I can't get because I used the token for it on the blueprint you can find and there are no more vendor quests to do to get more tokens as I have completed them all (i'm screwed lol).

There are 4 unlock able trinkets that combine some of the higher tier trinkets into one I've gotten one unlocked and cant figure out how to unlock the other 3.  The one I have is the shield/speed run trinket. There really isn't a lot of info out their from the community like there is for some games (Heroes of Ruin) so a lot of it is trial and error and while that's great sometimes it's frustrating (damn you trinkets)

My Last Word: Definitely recommend getting this game on a good sale (thank you summer sale 2021!!)it's a fun light hear-ted survival game. It does feel at times half done but get it at a good price and you wont be disappointed. (oh and if you're stuck on the Beast Master quest to tame two rabbits you need to bring them to the small structure next to him that's a miniature animal pen like the one in your crafting menu).

77295325.review:
The survivalists is very enjoyable to play alone or with others. 
If you don't find anyone you can play with, there are also the monkeys in the game who partly replace these players. 

The monkeys you will meet you must first help to free them or give them food. from then on they belong to your team and you can train them to do certain tasks for you.
They can find resources for you, stock them, you can also give them knowledge for the constructive part of the game, so that when things are built you have time to continue doing your thing. 
the monkeys can also become better at tasks as they do tasks more and as a result, for example, work faster or master several tasks.
you will also have to craft extra tools to give to the monkeys so that they can perform the tasks for you. 
You can also teach them how to fight so that when you explore, you can better defend yourself against wild beasts or native inhabitants. 

You will also often discover temples where you can find special items, i advice you never to enter such a temple unarmed.
when you are dead you drop all your items that you have on you on the spot, these items can be retrieved later at that place.
to avoid being killed you also have the option to teach your monkeys how to fight, this will greatly increase your chances of survival. the monkeys are also very useful for holding extra items when your inventory is full.

just like you, the monkeys will also lose hp while fighting, your job is to prepare food in time to heal or satisfy hunger. 
You won't have to drink water to survive but there is an energy meter. 
While running or taking resources you will have to keep an eye on that, you will get hungry faster if you keep overshooting this energy meter. 

The game offers you a series of recipes that you can prepare on a campfire. Some recipes only satisfy hunger, others also provide new HP. You can also eat directly from foods that you find in nature, but the prepared recipes will be much more useful and require fewer numbers for a worthy effect. 

You will also have to hunt for wildlife to make other recipes.
To hunt certain animals you will have to craft certain items, for example to catch fish. 
Or if you want to save yourself the hunting you can also craft traps and wait after you have placed them. 

you will also find treasure maps, notes, or diaries with useful information that will lead you to useful items or exceptional locations. 
the game will also offer many interesting quests through bottles washed up on the beach or through a mysterious stranger.

Online you have certain options as a host, so you can determine whether players / which players are allowed to build in your world or so you can also determine whether other players can also own monkeys, if not the monkeys that other players find will automatically join the host's team.

Tip: when going out for recources you'll have to tap the left mouse button. But when you hold the left mouse button then you will do a more powerfull attack which will be more effective and which will also save you time.

https://youtu.be/5GUAdBvUbzA

100475125.review:
This game has a lot going for it.  It looks very sharp overall.  There is a lot to build and seems like the map is pretty big but not -too- big.  You have monkeys!

That said this game is a hot mess.  Progression is poor.  Trying to get basalt rock made me pretty upset.  Not looking forward to grinding out tokens to get all the trinket blueprints (which you then have to craft) these couldn't have just been rewards outright?  Oh yeah, don't accidentally go to the volcano island first like I did you'll get wrecked.

Weapons degrade way too fast and repairs are costly.  Add in weapons for a monkey army and you have a bad time all around.

Speaking of monkeys, they are setup in such a way they are basically unusable.  Sure you can teach them a skill and they do it forever but this should have been done as follows:

-Teach a monkey to do X
-Monkey learns X and does X
-Monkey then has X as a learned trait that can be assigned in the menu without having to show the little bastard what to do again and again as needs changed

Also renaming monkeys is a terrible joke... whomever programmed that text box should be fired.

Not sure why the player character cannot level up outside of Trinkets.  Odd design choice for sure.

Controls are clunky and un-intuitive.  More often then not I give a monkey my weapon on accident and when I DO want to give them a weapon they run away before I can.  Monkeys surround you so you cannot interact with things.  It's just dismal. 

I wan't to like this game but it's get some pretty deep seeded issues that get in the way of fun.  Maybe one day it'll get there.

I played through the entire game and beat the main objective at the end. Took me around 37 Hours. 

After the first 10 it feels like you've done everything and there's nothing new to do. 

The constant raids are very annoying to deal with.

The ending is unsatisfying and disappointing.  

The game is meant to be a sandbox survival game, but the lack of sandbox tools and repetitive survival needs makes the game stale.

It was fun to play for the first time but the lack of content makes it forgettable and I am unlikely to go through with a second playthrough. 

I love the team's work and their games, but their recent "Escapists' brand games, (The Escapists 2) and (The Survivalists) have been abandoned too early on in development. 

I sincerely hope that this isn't a reoccurring trend and hope for better games with consistent updates.

77538133.review:
I found a post that summarizes how I feel about the title in it's present state; so I am going to paste those items here:

------------

I would skip purchasing this game. They say they're collecting all the feedback to work on improving the game but with the amount of common bugs that I've run into it seems like their "gathering "feedback" is just PR.

Common Bugs:
* Pressing Q, gathering all your monkeys around, hover over one monkey, click them and click Train. High chance that your character throws a banana to multiple monkeys instead of just the one you click.
-Workaround: Click and drag to select a single monkey. They use a grid system and when the monkeys gather around they'll each occupy a single grid.

* Logging into the game you'll notice that your monkeys that were trained for Combat decided to dismiss themselves. So everytime you log in you'll need to gather up the wandering monkeys and retrain them
-Workaround: You can set you monkeys to pose before you log out so you won't have to regather them but you'll still need to retrain.

*Placing markers on the map is very inaccurate, the markers rarely appear where you want them to.
- Workaround: Place a bunch of markers on map till one lands where you want it to then delete all the others.

** Several hours in you'll run into the "Wood/charcoal" bug. Basically makes random ghost Charcoal and Wood appear in monkeys inventories that are delivering ingredients to furnaces/fires/benches. The charcoal/wood that appears has only 25% durability and prevents the monkeys from putting them into the target inventory.
-Workaround: You need to SWAP items with the monkey and then they'll drop the ghost item. You won't be able to pick up that item but if you drop a similar item right on top of it, pick up the item and the ghost item disappears.
***DISCLAIMER*** Once this bug affects your save it'll start occurring often, so all production reliant on wood or charcoal will stop just as often. Example: I find a monkey that's bugged, go to him, swap items and clear the bug. He'll deliver one item successfully then get locked up on the delivery after. I've quit my 22 hour save because of this and don't think I'll be restarting.


Quality of Life Issues:
* UI designed with a mobile first mentality. UI looks like it's made for a phone game.

* Controls designed with controller/gamepad first mentality. Using mouse and keyboard is very buggy throughout the game, I'm guessing that's the reason the dev's only showcase the game while using a controller.

* Caves are useless. Just wall them up so bats won't come out at night.

* Decorative items are useless. In English, we call these items Trash. You can't do anything with these items except sell to a vendor and they're only worth 5 gold. Vendor doesn't care about damaged items, so just save up your damaged tools and sell them to him for ~40-120 gold.

* Monkeys assigned to deliver items to a chest will prioritize that chest you selected (even if there's a chest next to items they're picking up) but once it's full it seems like they'll pick any random chest within range instead of the next closest.

* When monkeys get knocked out, they lose what they've learned and start wandering.

* No limit on how far they can wander from their original position.

* Can't assign monkeys to guard base while you explore. If you're starting a new base and get raided, many monkeys will get knocked out and you'll have to retrain them all.

* Dungeons/Labrinyths/Vaults are all pretty much the same. Once you collect your 20 monkeys there's no point in revisiting them unless you're planning on collecting Legendary items of tools.

* Most Legendary Items are pointless. With how easy the game is, you don't need more than the blue items you get.

* Monkeys drop chests they're carrying upon getting attacked. While this feature is good if your monkey is trained in combat since they'll immediately start attacking, it's bad when you're moving bases around or travelling through overly thick forests since it becomes very easy to lose chests. It also seems like shark attacks make your monkeys drop the chests into the ocean instead of onto the boat.

-------
There are SO MANY quality of life items that are missing from this title that are survival game basics; and yet they are absent.   But the biggest crime here is when a majority of the focus of the game is the automation of tasks via monkey helpers; and THAT system is broken--the rest of the game falls apart.

77969952.review:
While it looks very interesting and the concept does sound fun, unfortunately the content is very much lacking.

The first (experimental) patch did fix some bugs and quality of life issues, but there remains far too many issues that ruin the experience.

Loading up a save game I found all my monkeys that were trained for attacking had forgotten their role. Later after a raid (which I have no way to possibly get back in time to assist with), I can see that while my defences worked, all my monkeys no longer had any roles assigned.

Assigning monkeys to specific roles as well as the user interface is somewhat lacking. It is rather annoying and the button prompts always assume an Xbox controller layout.

The first part to the game is very confusing to learn, such as:
*where to get more metal
*how to find the shop again
*how to open chests

The biggest issue I had was all the objects blocking my path. One must spend time either finding tiny gaps that cannot be seen, or a long time breaking rocks and chopping trees. This is made even worse when you have monkeys carrying chests that count as solid objects.

My 2nd biggest issue was monkeys would sometimes wander far from home, after you spend a short time on another part of the map, leaving you to have to fix it for every monkey every time you return. Followers would also forget that they are supposed to follow, after being attacked (which they cannot be told to ignore or run from).

It is worth noting that there is a lack of being able to save anywhere. You always have to return to your bed to save, which can take minutes of walking/navigating. This is even worse if you are the middle of something important, such as using a timed buff or inside a temple.

You will find yourself running out of things to do fast, while just repeating the same thing over and over for the same reward (with a different name/image).

I could easily have overlooked all the issues if the game were in early access, or a beta version.

Update: some bugs have been fixed, but content is still quite lacking and repetitive.l

156219385.review:
[h1][b] Just Okay [/b][/h1]
I decided I would play through this entire game before leaving a review with my final thoughts on it. 
[b]Overall, the gameplay loop is repetitive and shallow, and the core aspects of the game (survival/crafting) are severely lacking variety and room for ingenuity. If you need to scratch your survival/crafting itch, look elsewhere.[/b]


[h3][b]What it did Right[/b][/h3]
Some parts of the game kept me coming back, otherwise I would not have taken the time to reach the ending. These are the things I liked the most:

The artstyle for this game is consistent and adorable. Nothing feels out of place, and the sprites are very well done. [spoiler]The Red Panda spirit pet was particularly cute, and its idle animations were a nice touch.[/spoiler]

Automating tasks, roaming the map armed to the teeth, and striking goofy poses with your army of monkeys is very satisfying, especially toward the endgame. Once you have an abundance of resources and monkeys, you can set up a blueprint for a large base and watch as your primate contractors get to work constructing it in a hilariously short amount of time.


[h3][b] What it did Wrong [/b][/h3]
I want to preface this by saying the game is not [i]bad[/i], but the more I think about my experience, the more disappointed I am. This could have been another excellent title that keeps on giving, much like other more popular survival/crafting titles.

The crafting menus are all over the place and take some getting used to. Your menu for creating your base is separate from your menu for crafting essentials, and those menus have a second page you would miss if you were only halfway paying attention to the tooltips and tutorials. They could have easily fit these menus on one page, and I am not sure why they opted to split some of these. 

You slowly unlock recipes by crafting one item at a time within "crafting trees", which is how the game locks your progress. However, because you cannot see what comes next in the tree, you are forced to guess which item along the path unlocks the next MacGuffin that will allow you to craft what you actually need. This led to some minor frustrations as I had to basically trial and error my way to making any progress in the game.

The base building lacks variety. There are only a handful of walls, floors, and furniture types, the rest is all your work stations. The grid you build on feels restrictive, and you cannot rotate your blueprints. I never found myself feeling good about the way my base looked, but feeling like it was "good enough" given the limitations. In a game in which base building and crafting is a core mechanic, variety is what makes the game replayable and fun. This does not have that.

The main character is somehow unlikeable. Every time they have to do a small amount of work, they whine about how they should just get their monkeys to do it. Even worse, there are some areas of the game in which they spew an endless stream of whining, like [spoiler]the Swamp and the Volcano biomes. You have to spend a lot of time in these biomes if you want to progress, and as a result you have to spend a lot of time listening to the main character whine.[/spoiler]

The story is presented to you via logs you find scattered across the map, which are given to you in a random order. The way the final log is written feels less like a shocking reveal and more like an abrupt stop; as if they were halfway through development and decided this log was a good enough place to end it. Using logs to tell the story felt like a way to shirk having to write any amount of dialogue for the NPCs and a cheap way to extend the collectathon to the point in which gathering them just felt like a timesink.

The combat has very little depth, and worse, [b]sometimes doesn't work[/b]. There would be moments in which I would clearly see my weapon contact the enemy, I would hear the soundbite for the weapon striking my opponent, but their HP would not go down. I would have to readjust my position (sometimes hardly moving at all) for the game to register those hitbox collisions as valid. It made some combat encounters very frustrating, especially when dealing with larger groups of enemies. You eventually unlock [spoiler]legendary "elemental" weapons that ... whack things harder. There is literally no difference between these weapons' attacks and their counterparts except for how much damage they do.[/spoiler]

The "labyrinths" and their bosses were extremely disappointing. There are four of these in the game, one on each of the other islands. Since these islands have their own unique biomes, you would expect the labyrinths to follow that theme, but instead you are met with the same corridors, pits, crates, and fight rooms in every single one (albeit arranged in a random order). The only thing that changes is the enemy type featured inside, which is the same enemy type that exists outside the labyrinth already. The bosses [spoiler]are just resized, reskinned versions of said enemy type. Is it too much to ask for a unique mob? Or maybe something that has new attack patterns that are actually challenging instead of just making them bigger meat sponges? [/spoiler] Overall, it felt extremely lazy and rushed, and each one was more like a chore I was checking off my to-do list so I could reach the ending.

Speaking of, the ending is not satisfying. [spoiler] When you finally have the option to escape, a short cutscene plays. You sail away with all your monkeys on board, thankful you had their help throughout your journey. However, the monkeys knock you out and throw you overboard, and your character once again finds themselves stranded. I understand it was supposed to be cheeky--it was a game about surviving on remote islands with your monkey pals--but it honestly felt like the developers were laughing at me for wasting my time playing this game at all. You spend so much time doing the same gameplay loop over and over just to reach the end and be told that it was all a waste because you would just end up back where you started. [/spoiler]


[h3][b]Something Particularly Bad[/b][/h3]
It makes sense to give this its own category, as this is a glaring issue. In the game you can unlock "task tokens" which can be exchanged for blueprint recipes and other items. There are just enough of these to unlock every available blueprint BUT, it is possible to purchase the same blueprint twice, after which the game will not refund your task token. The only way to obtain task tokens is by completing quests that NPCs give out, and once they are completed, they cannot be repeated. If you accidentally purchase the same blueprint twice, the only way to get more task tokens is to “regenerate” your world, which resets your NPC quest progress and islands. However, it does not allow you to take anything with you except for items you store inside "The Mysterious Chest" and your monkeys. Any bases you built and resources you gathered that cannot fit inside the chest are lost forever.

This has been a known bug since v1.1.13 according to the wiki. This issue, combined with the hitbox issue I mentioned earlier, and the extremely lackluster dungeons and bosses, makes it clear the dev team either got lazy after release, had to rush this out, or some combination of the two.

[h3][b]Final Thoughts[/b][/h3]
I wanted to like this game. Survival/crafting games are my favorite genre, and this game had a look that was very enticing. Unfortunately it comes off somewhat soulless; like an amalgamation of things people like in other crafting games, outdated references, and very little depth across the board. Given more time, they could have developed more interesting boss fights, unique dungeons, and a story that felt a little more present than randomly placed journal entries. Instead we are left with an experience that feels like a hollowed-out re-skin of a game we have already played before.

117225425.review:
This game looks good on paper, but it's bogged down by a clunky UI, annoying combat, and an unsatisfying core loop. It shares the problem of a lot of survival-themed games where everything feels like another chore to manage.

The core monkey mechanic is the worst offender. The mimicry teaching mechanic is fun thematically, but in practice it's a 5 step process that takes upwards of a minute to get a monkey to do something that it's probably only going to do for a minute or so until it runs out of its tool or resource. If you ever give it any other command you have to go through that whole process again. 

The idea of exploring other islands is fun, but it's crushed by the raiding system because every 10 minutes or so you have to run back (technically you can build a bed on the new island and set that as home but that doesn't really feel in the spirit of things since you're encouraged to build defenses in your base). If you hand your monkeys weapons to help you fight, you have to individually retrain all of them. Walls are mostly useless because enemies spawn sporadically around your bed anyway.

The game would be markedly improved if monkeys remembered prior tasks and you can just set them through a menu. Alternatively, add the ability to equip every monkey with a weapon and a tool and have it automatically fight and then go back to work when there are no threats.

As a general rule for these kinds of games, I really think simply removing the item durability mechanic would improve the experience. It would significantly reduce the monkey micro management and reduce the amount of time you spend on the treadmill doing the same thing over and over again. For the record - in real life, I've used the same axe/splitting maul, shovels, and pickaxe for 15+ years. I've chopped down trees, split logs, broken up rocks, and dug holes over this time period. I've had to sharpen the axe once or twice. That's the extent of the maintenance these tools have required and none of them have spontaneously broken.

86186111.review:
[h1]Island Escapists[/h1]

[i]The Survivalists[/i], by the studio behind prison breakout game [i]The Escapists[/i], has your basic "explore and craft to escape the island" plot.

Hoo boy, is there a TON of crafting in this game.  No raw resource that drops is of much use without modification, not even the fruit that you can eat right away.

Recipes come in three basic styles.  Items crafted By Hand must have the items in your inventory.  Items made at crafting stations or as blueprints set on the ground do not need you to have all the items in inventory at once.  Instead, you can put just a few at a time until you have all you need.  These latter two styles also require the use of a "multitool," but it looks and sounds like a hammer, unless it's stirring food.

By Hand and every crafting station have their own crafting trees.  You unlock recipes by crafting the ones before it, so you cannot skip over all but the final recipe in the branch.  Crafting trees are organized logically, though.  Crafting a core component for the first time might unlock recipes using it, or you go through a series of upgrades, or other items in the category.

You'll find extensive crafting trees in another sense.  The more complicated builds require raw materials to be combined into components, and then those components are used in the end build, leading to possibly a couple dozen total steps from raw components to final product.  Crafting also takes time, from a second or two to an entire minute.  A good chuck of game time is waiting for crafting to finish.  (And just you wait until the endgame's build!)


Of course, you'll need to collect the raw materials before you start crafting.  Your personal inventory is limited to just 10 slots, but an upcoming update gives you a backpack.  Worse, there's no equipment slots.  You can wield only tools and weapons, no armor or amulets here, and they must be held in inventory.  And those tools and weapons suffer from durability.

On the other hand, the game is quite generous with most resources.  The game map itself is [i]ginormous[/i], around the size other games might consider for an entire planet.  It even resembles a planet, with "continents" that are actually several procedurally-generated islands, plus sandbars and rock formations.

Your midsize starting island has just the first, easy half of the resources with nothing more dangerous than a few aggro animals and enemies.  More dangerous biomes with advanced resources await you on larger islands.  Any one of the large islands contains a bit of everything, but the endgame requires you to visit the other large islands.

Another way the game is generous is in respawning treasure chests.  These spawn when you find a message in a bottle that gives you a "treasure map."  Smash the chest open, and you'll find what the map says:  Food, a tool, a weapon, or other items, and gold.

Anything in inventory can be dropped and safely left to persist forever.  Excess harvested resources can also be safely left on the ground, or disposed of in an upcoming update's refuse pit.

Storage chests are a bit more than their usual godsend.  While you can't color-code or label them, you can pick them up and tote them around, even while full!  This is like an extra or upgraded backpack.


Monkey friends are also here to help you.  Scattered on the islands are monkeys either trapped in cages or running wild.  Free a caged monkey or give a wild monkey the gift they desire, and they will become your helpers.

This becomes a literal "monkey see, monkey do" situation.  Toss them the right tool or weapon, enter Monkey Mimic Mode, and start the action you want them to do, and they will do it.  Your monkey friends can do any major game task you can do, from harvesting, putting resources in chests, supplying crafting stations, crafting, and combat, with the ability to level up beyond what your poor static avatar can do.  They can also carry chests.

The crafting system limits the monkey helper usefulness.  You can't tell Caesar or your own avatar to make axes until you run out of supplies; you have to keep feeding each individual recipe or see that the monkeys do it.  It is possible to set up a whole supply-and-crafting chain, but there's not much room in the safe alcove you start in, and you'll have to keep monitoring it.  The monkeys also have a tendency to lose focus and wander off once they don't have anything to do or once they wake up after getting knocked out.

But the monkeys are GREAT for harvesting resources and gathering them, and are a HUGE help in combat.


There's both hunger and stamina mechanics here.  Hunger grows with activity.  Get too hungry, and you lose health.  Stamina is of the "lemmee catch my breath a moment" variety, and only becomes a problem in combat.  Naturally, the food you cook act as potions and buffs.  Gathering enough food is a slight struggle until you put together a hunting/bodyguard posse of monkeys and have the metal to build an upgraded cooking station.


[b]Frustrations and Annoyances[/b]

It seems that every time I draft a review before finishing out a game I have to edit it.  Usually, this is to the negative.  This time around, it's to the positive.

I had a description of my annoyances with this game. (You have a surivival game on a bunch of islands, and you have neither farmable crops or effective fishing???  The raids are devastating to your early base!)

But, as I was finishing the game, the devs released a beta branch with a ton of features and tweaks, many courtesy of player feedback, that were meant to be eventually folded into the main game.  This branch promises to take care of most of my annoyances.  That patch will likely be in the main game in February or March of 2021.

One annoyance I had that might not be in that patch is how the game deals with respawns.  When you die, you lose all that is inventory.  (Not sure if the upcoming backpacks will also lose items on death.)  Sometimes, you respawn right where you died, or at the save point.  But other times, you respawn on a beach elsewhere on the island, forcing you to run to your items through dangerous territory without a weapon.  Fortunately, it's the same spot, so a player can just leave spare weapons nearby.


[b]The endgame's solid[/b]

Get past the annoyances and such and you'll find a good endgame, and a cute finale.  A final build to escape the strange islands will take hundreds of raw resources and a multi-step process.  Builder monkeys will help shave down the crafting time here.

But even then, you'll still need a few items housed in temple dungeons, and guarded by (disappointing) bosses.  To enter the temples, you'll need to buy keys off the game's lone shop.  In my game, the procedural randomness placed one temple smack in the middle of a dangerous island, but the others were all right off a beach.

Those temples hold some interesting and unique puzzles, including [i](groan)[/i] building so you and your monkey pals can pass over gaps.  Another puzzle type involved getting your monkeys to emote (wave, sit, handstand) on a trigger plate.  It was difficult to tell when the emotes were properly registered.



The game offers a mulitplayer mode, only of the "come visit and help" sort.  Your friends can take the place of monkeys, including the emote triggers in dungeons and more standard pressure plates.  They can also bring up to five monkeys with them.


I struggled with this game at times, but was still going to recommend it because I could finish it and because the devs were listening to the players and tweaking and adding stuff.  The tweaks that might have already come by the time you read this will definitely make it a more enjoyable game.
