77309394.review:
$25 price tag for a gameplay loop that lasts roughly 3-4 hours. 

If you enjoy doing the same thing over and over for no real reason then this is the game for you. In terms of progression you will easily reach a point with the tech trees and exploring that leaves you questioning why you're doing it in the first place, and that's pretty disappointing.

The games premise is establishing a base, growing a small army of monkeys, and above all, exploration and surviving. The problem there, however, is there is no reason to establish a base, exploration is pretty lack luster, and the "tech trees" are tiny. 

You'll quickly find yourself asking these questions - 
Why do you need a base in the first place? Well, to store materials of course. Why do you need materials? Well, to make a base of course. Where do I get better materials? Well, exploring of course. Why do I need to explore? To get better materials, of course. Why do I need better materials? To make a better base, of course. 

The monkeys are arguably the most interesting feature of the game that, while kind of helpful and neat, are only a marginally helpful version of basic automation that still requires player involvement to keep it moving. Need to build a structure? Well, better get ready to manually queue up every material in the process and stand there waiting for 5-10 minutes for the next step _you as the player_ will need to queue up for them. 

Overall, it's okay. Not worth $25, but okay.

138082330.review:
A C-grade survival game with F-grade implementation. Practically an unfinished beta being sold for $25.

To elaborate:
-UI is clunky or loves to work only half the time.
-Most progression is front-loaded to the first two islands.
-The fifth island is literally a combination of the third and fourth island biomes.
-Island hazards don't work, making the items to traverse them safely worthless.
-Puzzles are really easy, boiling down to "do you have enough monkeys to press these buttons?"
-Very few enemies, a good chunk of which are reskins.
-"Bosses" are upsized enemies with more HP.
-Taskmasters are banal busywork. They shouldn't be relegated to 1 per island, especially because some like the Salesman have tasks designed for early game despite being on the last island. They also unlock the best tools in the game.
-Task Tokens are finite, but the Mysterious Stranger can sell already-learned blueprints, wasting tokens and locking you out of other items.
-Most pets and trinkets do too little for how much effort it takes to get them, save for ones like Harvest.
-Blood moons happen far too often. They renew resources so that's fine, but each one summons a raid on the player that is usually too easy to matter and is just a waste of time.
-Monkeys can get stuck out-of-bounds or otherwise stop listening to you, requiring use of a summoning banana to un-bork them.
-Monkey work range is annoyingly small, especially for base work. They can be told to chop trees, then stop and say "No more trees!" when there are ten right next to them.
-Food system is baffling with how useless most of them are. High-end items are usually overshadowed by cheap food (e.g. meat pasties), especially since you can spam food to heal.
-Base building is exceedingly tedious. I spent a lot of time collecting resources for it even during lategame.
-Teleporters sometimes refuse to bring your monkeys with you. Get ready to waste charges over this.
-Multiplayer progression is tied to the host. You want to bring more monkeys or craft trinkets? Play solo.
-YMMV on this, but the ending disappointed me for the effort it took to get there.

-The last update was in June 2021, meaning the current broken state of the game is A-OK by the devs nearly 2 years later.

Monkey automation is the one neat idea this game has and the artstyle is pretty good, but cool ideas and decent graphics do not a fun game make.

127713878.review:
I was extremely disappointed by this game. Survival crafting/base building is my genre and I have/played 1000's of hours of games in that category. I picked this up on sale thinking the art looked very charming and the game had a good premise. 

The idea of being able to automate things so you don't have to do tedious tasks is a good one! However, the process of setting up those automations is finnicky, frustrating, and downright annoying. Sometimes I craft things by hand (which takes much longer) just to avoid trying to select a monkey, give them the appropriate tool, and demonstrate what I want done. You have to do this every time you want to make a change in your production lines. Did you select the right monkeys? Who knows! they all stand on top of each other and move whenever you take a step. 

Let me give you an example of a typical process of setting up a temporary base on a new island in early/mid game: Go to a new island with your handful of monkeys, bring ALL your tools because if you need a tool, the process to create a basic crafting bench takes 5 whole minutes, 3 ingredients, and 4 inventory slots to complete. You have very few inventory slots and will spend roughly 1/3 of this game tossing stuff out of your inventory and nearly 1/2 of the game managing chests. 
Then to make a basic tool takes 4 more ingredients (2 of which require 2 steps). If you want to avoid the long crafting time, you can reassign your monkeys to do it, but that will take another minute, at which point you'd rather just sit there and craft it yourself. 
In summary, making a crafting bench and a single tool takes roughly ten minutes, several different ingredients, throwing stuff out of my inventory to make room for all of them, and a bunch of micromanaging my monkeys which are supposed to make my life EASIER. 

I want to explore the world, which I think is one of the strengths of this game, but the exploration is an agonizing process of overpreparing, micromanaging inventory and monkeys, squeezing things into chests, and mostly being a pain in the ass. 

23 hours in, I realized this game wasn't even fun, and the rewards I get for progressing in the game leads to more of the same annoying, frustrating, tedious gameplay. 

Things that would improve the game, in my opinion: A complete re-work of the monkeys. They are there to make your life easier, not more frustrating. For example, only having to "teach" a monkey once, and then being able to assign them freely to tasks without having to do the whole process again. Dedicated tools or a small inventory for monkeys so I don't have to carry multiple tools for every monkey anytime I leave my base.
Better organization tools for chests, such as filters. 
MORE. INVENTORY. SPACE. (or fewer intermediary items needed to craft something simple) Why can't a crafting bench require only wood, for example? It would greatly improve QOL. Balancing can be addressed elsewhere. 

Cute game with a great premise but the gameplay is about as fun as yanking my fingernails out.

153227698.review:
I completed pretty much everything in the game, and my short answer is: 
Yes, the game is worth it on sale, and you'll most likely have a fun time with it.

A more detailed review:
The main mechanic, monkey labor, is a somewhat fun, but often frustrating mechanic. You'll likely be spending a lot of time standing around while waiting for your monkeys to finish certain things for you. But, this comes with the benefit that you can use this time to go around and adventure around the several islands. Though, with adventuring comes a rough apple you're going to have to bite through.

Combat. I won't sugarcoat it, but the combat in this game is very rough. Not in a, it's very hard kind of way, but in a very buggy kind of way. You'll often find yourself missing hits you definitely were supposed to, and somehow hitting things you definitely missed. Sometimes you'll just get pulled back and hit to a location you were previously. The best way to describe the combat is that it feels like you're playing with heavy latency.

Still, despite it's shortcomings, the Survivalist is a somewhat fun experience if you're fan of the survival game genre. It does things a lot of other survival games do, and some it does a little better, some it does a little worse. All in all, I'd rate the game a 7/10.

96527614.review: I immediately fell in love with the art style of this game, so it was very tempting after the big patch and a 50% OFF sale. I played it with two friends and we had a good time exploring the island, building a base, fighting animals and monsters and delving into dungeons.  This is one of those games where you just want to play another hour to unlock more crafting recipes and enhance your base, weapons and tools. It's a proven but still addictive concept that works just as good as in other games of the genre. That said, the game comes with a fair share of problems. The crafting is very slow and to speed up things you need to find and train apes. So this becomes one of those "automation crafting" games, but the system is a mess. Especially in multiplayer when everyone can control the apes and crafting stations. It's just way too inconvenient to be fun or effective. This leads to the next problem of the game: The UI. It's not very intuitive and the crafting stations often come with sub-menus and it just feels convoluted what item you can craft at what station. So expect some getting used to and frustration while trying to escape the island. And a friendly hint for visitors of other players islands: You don't get some of the critical crafting recipes, even when the game tells you that you unlocked them. A friend spent almost an hour trying to craft a bomb only to realize that the recipe didn't unlock at his crafting station but only mine because I was the host of the game. An oversight that should have been patched a long time ago. Still, despite some of the shortcomings, this is a fun and very charming crafting/survival game that is more on the casual side and easy to recommend for up to four friends that want some relaxing adventures.
